description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals show is based around the released exam objectives for SECFND Exam 210-250. The show will cover every exam objective to help prepare those interested in becoming CCNA CyberOps certified.  The show aids those preparing for the first of two exams leading to that certification by helping understand cybersecurity basics, foundational networking and security knowledge and develop skills needed in preparation for the second (SECOPS) exam.

episodes.description: This is the first episode in the Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals course which is geared to help you obtain the CCNA Cyber Ops certification. 00:25:34.780 --> 00:25:39.398

00:25:39.398 --> 00:25:44.020

00:25:49.320 --> 00:25:52.160
From this point on,

00:25:52.160 --> 00:25:55.600
It is just checking to see if
the rest of the data can be read,

00:25:55.600 --> 00:25:57.540
and that's where we have Layer 6.

00:25:57.540 --> 00:26:01.610
And then finally, it gets to that
point where we are now sending it on

00:26:01.610 --> 00:26:06.750

00:26:06.750 --> 00:26:10.760

00:26:10.760 --> 00:26:13.420
when you get through
the entire process here,

00:26:13.420 --> 00:26:17.970

00:26:17.970 --> 00:26:22.083

00:26:33.690 --> 00:26:37.090

00:26:41.880 --> 00:26:46.060

>> And that really is kind

fundamentals, fundamentals.

If you don't have this concept down,

make sure you get this concept down

I think it's a pretty beneficial or

Now even though the OSI model is pretty

the way that we believe that end-to-end

That particular model in itself was

30

And what I mean by that is that

First and foremost the biggest

00:02:38.270 --> 00:02:43.990

00:02:43.990 --> 00:02:48.210

And if you're talking about

layer and layers where as TCP/IP has
that flexibility to go ahead and

>> Yeah, both of them have that

describe that better in terms of

they didn't they didn't have a problem

But by that point, you had a fast and

The IP, we're just gonna stick with that.

00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:45.850
We're just gonna take that and go.

They didn't even ask.

They didn't have to kind of wait and

It was essentially done and they said,

Let's take a look at my machine, and that

and make sure that we understand the paths

I say the idea of contending with

>> Okay, that's what it really means,

00:06:05.440 --> 00:06:07.230
yeah, great instead of

Let me show you what

That if we take the OSI model and

00:06:27.130 --> 00:06:28.870

We're not really that concerned.

00:08:22.431 --> 00:08:25.794

that's what you end up seeing, so

Cisco really does tend to

as much as we implement it along here, is

which is, of course, the seven-layer

And in Cisco textbooks,

00:08:56.210 --> 00:09:01.010

The only difference here is that they've

00:09:06.320 --> 00:09:07.510
I wonder who they got that from.

168
00:09:08.808 --> 00:09:11.666
Look at that, the OSI model as well,
because they realized

00:26:52.530 --> 00:26:55.810

on your network forever.

475
00:26:55.810 --> 00:26:59.310

476
00:26:59.310 --> 00:27:01.380
>> Yeah it's kind of
wasted at some point here.

477
00:27:01.380 --> 00:27:02.980
But if you statically assign it, and

00:27:02.980 --> 00:27:06.640
nobody ever uses that address, you can

479
00:27:06.640 --> 00:27:09.650
But now if that computer ever turns
back on, you'll now have conflicting

00:27:09.650 --> 00:27:14.390

00:27:14.390 --> 00:27:15.968
Not ever a good thing.

00:27:15.968 --> 00:27:16.731
>> No bueno.

483
00:27:16.731 --> 00:27:18.920
>> Yep,
once you have that on your computer and

00:27:18.920 --> 00:27:22.730
it's configured,
that is when your computer responds back.

00:27:22.730 --> 00:27:27.890

00:27:27.890 --> 00:27:30.890
I'm gonna take that lease,

00:27:30.890 --> 00:27:35.170
So that's where we see that idea

488
00:27:35.170 --> 00:27:38.744
And then the DHCP server will essentially
mark that address as being list

489
00:27:38.744 --> 00:27:39.339
out to you.

490
00:27:39.339 --> 00:27:43.127
And once that's happen, they will send
you back an acknowledgment saying,

491
00:27:43.127 --> 00:27:44.800
I've got you as a lease.

492
00:27:44.800 --> 00:27:49.070
And so you'll be able to use that
address until lease time is expired.

493
00:27:49.070 --> 00:27:55.150
Lease can be set for anytime that you want
to, how fast, how long that you wanted to.

494
00:27:55.150 --> 00:27:59.666
Like in Windows, I think the DHCP
server by default is eight days long.

495
00:27:59.666 --> 00:28:02.912
But on other types of appliances
that you might see it on,

496
00:28:02.912 --> 00:28:06.848
it may be as short as 24 hours or
eight hours or whatever it might be.

497
00:28:06.848 --> 00:28:12.520
And it just depends on how much your
network changes, is what you might have.

498
00:28:12.520 --> 00:28:15.570
So for example,
if you're in a regular LAN network and

499
00:28:15.570 --> 00:28:17.100
you don't have a lot of
devices that change.

500
00:28:17.100 --> 00:28:20.624
People aren't bringing computers in,
aren't taking computers off network,

501
00:28:20.624 --> 00:28:21.882
you may leave it and go look.

502
00:28:21.882 --> 00:28:26.090
We'll set it for two weeks,
if we want to and that's perfectly fine.

503
00:28:26.090 --> 00:28:29.110
But if you have an environment in

00:28:29.110 --> 00:28:32.150
moving in and out of that network and
you want to make sure that

505
00:28:32.150 --> 00:28:35.250
those particular addresses can
be reused over and over again.

506
00:28:35.250 --> 00:28:38.370
You set a shorter lease
time is what you might do.

507
00:28:38.370 --> 00:28:42.520
For example, if you have a guest
wireless network, you may not set it for

508
00:28:42.520 --> 00:28:45.515

at least for eight days.

509
00:28:45.515 --> 00:28:47.725
You might set it where you
only extend the lease for

510
00:28:47.725 --> 00:28:50.295
that address for, let's say,
two hours, maybe.

511
00:28:50.295 --> 00:28:53.925
Or maybe, four hours, if you know that
that's the max that a vendor might

512
00:28:53.925 --> 00:28:56.272
be on your network, or
a guest might be on your network.

513
00:28:56.272 --> 00:28:58.762
And that way, at the end of the four

514
00:28:58.762 --> 00:28:59.602
It's perfectly fine, they can.

515
00:28:59.602 --> 00:29:02.586
>> Better allocation if you have smaller
IP address pool then it's just using them

00:29:02.586 --> 00:29:03.349
more efficiently.

517
00:29:03.349 --> 00:29:07.793
>> Right, and it's managing better because
it could be that if you lease it for

00:29:07.793 --> 00:29:11.750
eight days, you might find out if

00:29:11.750 --> 00:29:15.430

00:29:15.430 --> 00:29:18.290

00:29:18.290 --> 00:29:20.020

00:29:23.290 --> 00:29:26.450

00:29:26.450 --> 00:29:28.180

00:29:28.180 --> 00:29:28.920

00:29:40.580 --> 00:29:41.810

00:29:41.810 --> 00:29:44.080

00:30:46.010 --> 00:30:50.420

00:30:50.420 --> 00:30:52.210

00:31:03.850 --> 00:31:06.450

00:31:06.450 --> 00:31:10.130

00:31:10.130 --> 00:31:13.220

00:31:13.220 --> 00:31:16.800

559
00:31:16.800 --> 00:31:19.140

00:31:19.140 --> 00:31:23.800

00:31:23.800 --> 00:31:25.440

00:31:25.440 --> 00:31:31.710

00:31:31.710 --> 00:31:36.050

00:31:36.050 --> 00:31:40.440

00:31:40.440 --> 00:31:44.740

00:31:44.740 --> 00:31:48.600

00:31:48.600 --> 00:31:49.860

00:26:41.570 --> 00:26:45.490
we start talking about this idea
of different devices, okay?

484
00:26:45.490 --> 00:26:50.150
So that's a good kind of fundamental
review at least of kind of

485
00:26:50.150 --> 00:26:52.585
the first three things that we
have to worry about, right?

486
00:26:52.585 --> 00:26:54.150
We've talked about routers,

487
00:26:54.150 --> 00:26:56.384
we've talked about switches, and
even a little bit about hubs.

488
00:26:56.384 --> 00:26:59.770
We still got a few more to go, but I think
I'm not sure running out of time here.

489
00:26:59.770 --> 00:27:01.590
>> You are correct there Ronnie, and yes,

490
00:27:01.590 --> 00:27:05.320
just to recap like you said we were
able to take a look at our routers.

491
00:27:05.320 --> 00:27:06.972
Remember that's a layer three device.

492
00:27:06.972 --> 00:27:10.854
We've moved down to layer
two to examine switches and

493
00:27:10.854 --> 00:27:15.905
then we also went down to the physical
layer to examine our hubs.

494
00:27:15.905 --> 00:27:16.535
Stay tuned,

495
00:27:16.535 --> 00:27:20.955
we do have information headed your way for
additional networking devices.

496
00:27:20.955 --> 00:27:23.655
But for this episode,
I'm gonna go ahead and sign off.

497
00:27:23.655 --> 00:27:25.675
As your show host, I'm Cherokee Boose.

498
00:27:25.675 --> 00:27:26.535
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

499
00:27:26.535 --> 00:27:29.697
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

500
00:27:29.697 --> 00:27:35.801
[MUSIC]

501
00:27:35.801 --> 00:27:38.566
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee continue to examine networking hardware. First, you will learn about an older device called a bridge. Secondly, they discuss more modern products such as Wireless Access Points (WAP) and Wireless LAN Controller (WLC).
episodes.title: Describe Networking Devices Operations Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:02.903
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.903 --> 00:00:08.006
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.006 --> 00:00:12.127
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.127 --> 00:00:15.317
>> Welcome to your
Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals series.

5
00:00:15.317 --> 00:00:20.500
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose,
this is actually a part two,

6
00:00:20.500 --> 00:00:23.490
where we will be examining
network device operations.

7
00:00:23.490 --> 00:00:28.410
In the previous episode, Ronnie was able
to explain the functions of switches,

8
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:29.900
routers, and hubs.

9
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:32.970
So let's go ahead and welcome him
back in studio today, thank you for

10
00:00:32.970 --> 00:00:34.480
joining us today Ronnie.

11
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:36.480
And what will we be starting with today?

12
00:00:36.480 --> 00:00:39.951
What device will we be examining,
if I can speak correctly?

13
00:00:39.951 --> 00:00:42.778
>> [LAUGH] Well, we're gonna be taking
a look at three different devices here.

14
00:00:42.778 --> 00:00:46.370
I'm gonna talk about bridges just briefly,
and then we'll spend little time

15
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:50.680
talking about wireless access point and
also wireless LAN controllers.

16
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:54.100
Just to make sure that we understand
what are the typical types of devices we

17
00:00:54.100 --> 00:00:55.040
generally see.

18
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:58.220
Now bridges is the only
one that's really kind of

19
00:00:58.220 --> 00:01:00.810
not going to be seen on today's network.

20
00:01:00.810 --> 00:01:02.490
I don't wanna say that you won't see them,

21
00:01:02.490 --> 00:01:06.380
but I'm pretty sure you're not gonna
see them, cuz just as soon as I say

22
00:01:06.380 --> 00:01:08.210
that somebody will write and
be like, no, we still use one.

23
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:08.900
>> I have one on my network.

24
00:01:08.900 --> 00:01:10.060
>> Yeah, I still have one on my network.

25
00:01:10.060 --> 00:01:13.010
>> So I'm definitely not gonna tell
you that you're not gonna see one.

26
00:01:13.010 --> 00:01:15.445
But let's talk about what
a bridge is versus a switch,

27
00:01:15.445 --> 00:01:19.140
cuz usually that's the question
I get most of the time, right.

28
00:01:19.140 --> 00:01:20.080
What do bridges do?

29
00:01:20.080 --> 00:01:24.710
Well, bridges, they forward data,
they filter data, they flood data.

30
00:01:24.710 --> 00:01:25.950
What do switches do?

31
00:01:25.950 --> 00:01:27.960
Forward, filter, and flood data.

32
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:31.550
That sounds like they're
pretty much the same.

33
00:01:31.550 --> 00:01:34.910
Bridges they make decisions
based off the MAC address table.

34
00:01:34.910 --> 00:01:39.540
Well switches make decisions based
off the MAC address table as well, so

35
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.460
when it comes down to what the real
differences are between them,

36
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:44.870
it really comes down to two things.

37
00:01:44.870 --> 00:01:48.710
One is port density,
switches tend to have more than,

38
00:01:48.710 --> 00:01:52.990
well what bridges will have in terms of
the sheer number of ports on the devices.

39
00:01:52.990 --> 00:01:56.270
Even if you don't have a four port switch,
four port bridge though,

40
00:01:56.270 --> 00:01:58.598
would be pretty expensive.

41
00:01:58.598 --> 00:02:02.710
Usually they had two, three ports at max,
a lot of times, right.

42
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:04.605
But when you go to 48 port switches,

43
00:02:04.605 --> 00:02:08.630
well you don't tend to have 48 port
bridges anymore, even though technically

44
00:02:08.630 --> 00:02:14.740
you could say that it is actually a bridge
if you want to talk about that technology.

45
00:02:14.740 --> 00:02:18.400
Even technology we use in switching
on bridges it actually comes from

46
00:02:18.400 --> 00:02:19.308
bridge terminology.

47
00:02:19.308 --> 00:02:24.150
For example, if you talk about the idea of
spanning-tree protocol, the actual terms

48
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:28.940
that we use in spanning-tree protocol
to initiate all the different things,

49
00:02:28.940 --> 00:02:31.355
is really from bridges
more than anything else.

50
00:02:31.355 --> 00:02:32.630
Cuz you hear about root-bridge,

51
00:02:32.630 --> 00:02:36.760
you hear about the other things that
are out there, but that's pretty much it.

52
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:42.370
And so they all come from the bridge, and
that's because bridges proceeded switches

53
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:48.410
in terms of their arrival on
technology into the world, right.

54
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:50.230
So what is the real big difference?

55
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:52.790
At the beginning when bridges
started making their decisions

56
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:57.560
on using MAC addresses,
that was a very slow process.

57
00:02:57.560 --> 00:03:03.520
Reason why it was slow is cuz asics
weren't really invented for bridges yet.

58
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:05.650
Could they still forward data
based in the same process?

59
00:03:05.650 --> 00:03:10.390
Yes, bu the advent of asics
into the switching world,

60
00:03:10.390 --> 00:03:14.110
is really what made the difference,
and made, of course, switches then,

61
00:03:14.110 --> 00:03:18.090
much faster and much more expensive, and
be able to have more port density on them.

62
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:20.500
It really did help
the nature of networking.

63
00:03:20.500 --> 00:03:24.670
So bridges, even though they operate,
they operate relatively slow,

64
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:27.690
they don't have as much port density,
but their functionality is

65
00:03:27.690 --> 00:03:32.320
essentially identical to what you'll
see in terms of a switch today.

66
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:33.980
Can you still use them if you want to?

67
00:03:33.980 --> 00:03:36.230
Yes, are they gonna be insanely slow?

68
00:03:36.230 --> 00:03:39.500
Yes, and that is because they're
expecting you to take that bridge,

69
00:03:39.500 --> 00:03:43.060
plug it into a hub, and that's really
what they're expecting you to do.

70
00:03:43.060 --> 00:03:46.370
If you have 48 different devices,
they expect to see all your devices

71
00:03:46.370 --> 00:03:50.250
plugged into a hub, and then plugged
into that switch for that one port.

72
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:52.000
And then they make a decision
on which of those two

73
00:03:52.000 --> 00:03:54.240
ports they're actually
sending data out of.

74
00:03:54.240 --> 00:03:57.880
So, that's where you'll see that
idea of what a bridge will be.

75
00:03:57.880 --> 00:04:01.290
You'll probably not see them on
the network, but, like I said, just

76
00:04:01.290 --> 00:04:05.070
in time that I say that, somebody will
post in our forums, we still use bridges.

77
00:04:05.070 --> 00:04:06.930
Well, that proved me wrong right there,

78
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:10.790
so, I'm gonna say you'll probably not,
but you might see it.

79
00:04:10.790 --> 00:04:13.620
>> So just understanding the
functionality, what they do, what layer

80
00:04:13.620 --> 00:04:19.030
they operate on, which would be layer two,
and just the general idea of that device.

81
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:21.530
>> It really is, it really comes
down to it's the same thing,

82
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:22.640
it's a layer two device.

83
00:04:22.640 --> 00:04:28.250
It does work, but very slow by comparison
to the modern switches that we see today.

84
00:04:28.250 --> 00:04:31.170
And if you have a choice between them,
always pick a switch, always.

85
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:32.420
>> Got it.
>> Yeah, by far,

86
00:04:32.420 --> 00:04:35.740
make sure you pick up that
idea of the switch, okay.

87
00:04:35.740 --> 00:04:38.310
So that's all we're really
gonna say about the idea of

88
00:04:38.310 --> 00:04:41.980
bridges when it comes down to
anything else that we're doing here.

89
00:04:41.980 --> 00:04:45.210
The other one that we
wanna talk about is really

90
00:04:45.210 --> 00:04:46.760
probably one of the more popular devices.

91
00:04:46.760 --> 00:04:51.220
So we go from the most obscure device that
you can possibly find on today's networks,

92
00:04:51.220 --> 00:04:52.390
Hubs and bridges.

93
00:04:52.390 --> 00:04:54.990
I'm going to say Hubs are pretty
much right about there the same as

94
00:04:54.990 --> 00:04:56.200
bridges today.

95
00:04:56.200 --> 00:04:59.870
But the device you're probably just about
guaranteed to find in corporate networks

96
00:04:59.870 --> 00:05:04.670
today, of course, is gonna be some
type of wireless connection, right.

97
00:05:04.670 --> 00:05:08.940
Wireless networks have become insanely
popular today, and that is because of

98
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:14.620
the advent of not only things like mobile
devices, portability devices like laptops.

99
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:17.680
But because of mobile devices
like smartphones and tablets

100
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:21.630
that you tend to see, and they don't
tend to have a physical network adapter.

101
00:05:21.630 --> 00:05:24.250
So even on the machine
I'm using right here,

102
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:26.190
it doesn't actually have
a physical network adapter.

103
00:05:26.190 --> 00:05:30.660
I had to actually buy an actual adapter
that plugs into the port itself.

104
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:32.515
So you will still see those two.

105
00:05:32.515 --> 00:05:37.254
>> Well sure, and it's just so convenient,
especially in environments like hospitals,

106
00:05:37.254 --> 00:05:40.554
where the doctors and
personnel are moving from room to room.

107
00:05:40.554 --> 00:05:43.533
And we've got our medical
equipment that needs to,

108
00:05:43.533 --> 00:05:47.462
instead of connecting over the wired
connection every single time,

109
00:05:47.462 --> 00:05:50.620
it's just an easier way
of doing things now.

110
00:05:50.620 --> 00:05:54.930
>> It really is because it no longer
tethers you to a single location, right.

111
00:05:54.930 --> 00:05:59.160
If you're connected to a physical switch,
well the longest and ultimate

112
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:03.310
distance that you have is the length of
that cable, and that's pretty much it.

113
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:04.500
But with wireless though,

114
00:06:04.500 --> 00:06:07.650
you can travel within the range
of that wireless connection.

115
00:06:07.650 --> 00:06:09.760
So if it's inside of an office area,

116
00:06:09.760 --> 00:06:11.960
you don't have to be tethered
to your desk anymore.

117
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:12.830
You can move around and

118
00:06:12.830 --> 00:06:16.780
you can have that connection, and
still be connected and do that.

119
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:19.160
Let's take a look at my diagram
to help us out just briefly here.

120
00:06:20.230 --> 00:06:21.900
When it comes down to
wireless access points,

121
00:06:21.900 --> 00:06:25.760
there's really two types of wireless
access point, I only drew one here.

122
00:06:25.760 --> 00:06:31.360
Or made a diagram for one, which is this
idea of a wired and wireless access point.

123
00:06:31.360 --> 00:06:35.776
So this is kinda the combo device that we
tend to see that we buy out of brick and

124
00:06:35.776 --> 00:06:37.635
mortar stores, all right.

125
00:06:37.635 --> 00:06:40.395
If you've ever gone in and asked for
a wireless router and you didn't know

126
00:06:40.395 --> 00:06:44.695
exactly what you were doing, that's
actually a multi-layer device, okay.

127
00:06:44.695 --> 00:06:48.535
There's a router on it, so if you actually
turn your wireless router, so even,

128
00:06:48.535 --> 00:06:51.625
don't do it right now during the middle
of the show, cuz you'll get disconnected.

129
00:06:51.625 --> 00:06:53.465
But if you turned that
wireless router around and

130
00:06:53.465 --> 00:06:55.455
you see one of those ports that's
usually marked a different color,

131
00:06:55.455 --> 00:06:59.170
a lot of times it says WAN on it or
Internet on it.

132
00:06:59.170 --> 00:07:02.250
Well that's actually a router
port directly on your device.

133
00:07:02.250 --> 00:07:06.290
So that's a layer three device,
the other four ports that you have where

134
00:07:06.290 --> 00:07:08.775
you can physically plug in
those ethernet cables to.

135
00:07:08.775 --> 00:07:13.170
Well that's actually a switch, a little
four port switch or five port switch,

136
00:07:13.170 --> 00:07:14.640
whatever it might be.

137
00:07:14.640 --> 00:07:16.679
So that's actually a switch, but

138
00:07:16.679 --> 00:07:21.053
the other one though is actually
the antenna that you have on that device.

139
00:07:21.053 --> 00:07:27.910
Which is actually going to be a wireless
hub, so a hub is a layer one device, okay.

140
00:07:27.910 --> 00:07:31.378
So we have three different connections
when you start talking about something

141
00:07:31.378 --> 00:07:32.300
like this.

142
00:07:32.300 --> 00:07:34.290
If you go out to the store and
buy something.

143
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:37.600
It allows people to directly connect
in wired if they need to, or

144
00:07:37.600 --> 00:07:40.230
wirelessly by using this access point.

145
00:07:40.230 --> 00:07:43.990
Which is also, like I said,
generally a wireless Hub.

146
00:07:43.990 --> 00:07:46.700
And then we can also connect
out to the internet, and

147
00:07:46.700 --> 00:07:49.700
that would actually be a WAN port,
which means it does routing.

148
00:07:50.810 --> 00:07:53.350
So this device is a multi-function device,

149
00:07:53.350 --> 00:07:57.380
is really what it is even though they
call it a wireless router, it does that.

150
00:07:57.380 --> 00:08:02.520
Now we're really focusing in on the idea
of the wireless access point itself.

151
00:08:02.520 --> 00:08:06.550
Remember that when we talked about
the idea of hubs in a previous episode,

152
00:08:06.550 --> 00:08:09.870
we really had to kind of remind
ourselves that it shares the bandwidth.

153
00:08:09.870 --> 00:08:14.260
And that's important, because when we
have two devices that try to communicate

154
00:08:14.260 --> 00:08:16.120
with it at the exact same time,

155
00:08:16.120 --> 00:08:19.320
we normally end up getting what we
call a collision domain, right.

156
00:08:19.320 --> 00:08:23.690
We end up having where the data will
essentially just kind of collide and

157
00:08:23.690 --> 00:08:25.470
then would drop the packets.

158
00:08:25.470 --> 00:08:30.640
Well, then that means on a wireless
network, right, we would still

159
00:08:30.640 --> 00:08:35.020
have the same thing that would happen on a
hub, because that's what it functions as.

160
00:08:35.020 --> 00:08:40.680
But it doesn't, because instead of using
that CSMACD for collision detection,

161
00:08:40.680 --> 00:08:44.870
use something that we call CSMACA for
collision avoidance.

162
00:08:44.870 --> 00:08:49.200
And this also plays something a little bit
tricky on the way that people access this.

163
00:08:49.200 --> 00:08:53.391
So, inside of our wireless network right
now, if I remember just a couple of hours

164
00:08:53.391 --> 00:08:57.037
ago I was counting up and there were
probably about 30 people that were

165
00:08:57.037 --> 00:08:59.854
using our wireless access
point at that point in time.

166
00:08:59.854 --> 00:09:02.735
Now, when you think about that,
that sounds like it's a simultaneous

167
00:09:02.735 --> 00:09:06.065
connection, all 30 people are connected
wirelessly exactly at the same time.

168
00:09:06.065 --> 00:09:11.074
But in reality it's not, everybody is
really lining up, taking their own turn

169
00:09:11.074 --> 00:09:16.255
accessing that antenna, if there's only
a single antenna on that access point.

170
00:09:16.255 --> 00:09:19.230
If there's multiple antennas, of course,
multiple people can access it.

171
00:09:19.230 --> 00:09:21.860
But if there's only one antenna,
they would individually,

172
00:09:21.860 --> 00:09:25.530
one at a time, be sending or
receiving data on that.

173
00:09:25.530 --> 00:09:29.600
And it happens so fast because we
don't realize it in milliseconds, but

174
00:09:29.600 --> 00:09:31.360
it is actually just one of us at a time.

175
00:09:31.360 --> 00:09:34.180
So with 30 people,
they're essentially lining up and saying,

176
00:09:34.180 --> 00:09:37.710
can I use the access point, can I use the
access point, can I use the access point.

177
00:09:37.710 --> 00:09:40.880
But for us it happens so quickly we
just think it's simultaneous but

178
00:09:40.880 --> 00:09:45.110
it's really not, so that's what you
actually end up seeing there too.

179
00:09:45.110 --> 00:09:48.860
Okay, so
in that aspect of the access point itself,

180
00:09:49.860 --> 00:09:52.140
you'll end up having to worry
about things like that.

181
00:09:52.140 --> 00:09:55.390
Because that will kind
of tell you whether or

182
00:09:55.390 --> 00:09:59.940
not you have too many people on the access
point at the same time as well.

183
00:09:59.940 --> 00:10:03.740
And these things have to be
configured to make sure that you

184
00:10:03.740 --> 00:10:05.440
have DHCP running over them.

185
00:10:05.440 --> 00:10:06.970
That they have the right default gateway,

186
00:10:06.970 --> 00:10:09.490
everything is actually connected
the way that we want to.

187
00:10:09.490 --> 00:10:12.300
There's also what is called
a lightweight access point.

188
00:10:12.300 --> 00:10:15.628
So instead of you doing direct
configurations right here,

189
00:10:15.628 --> 00:10:18.098
it is just an access
point that acts as a hub.

190
00:10:18.098 --> 00:10:22.769
And the configuration is received from
somewhere else, and that is when we move

191
00:10:22.769 --> 00:10:26.545
into the realm of what we call
a wireless LAN controller, okay.

192
00:10:26.545 --> 00:10:30.539
In a wireless LAN controller,
it's exactly like it sounds.

193
00:10:30.539 --> 00:10:32.838
We can set up access points
wherever we want to,

194
00:10:32.838 --> 00:10:35.850
make sure they're connected
back to this device.

195
00:10:35.850 --> 00:10:41.220
And now we can actually have a single
configuration on that LAN controller, and

196
00:10:41.220 --> 00:10:47.020
then we can push out the configurations
in the way that we want to,

197
00:10:47.020 --> 00:10:50.080
one to the cafeteria,
to auditorium, to the library.

198
00:10:50.080 --> 00:10:53.800
We could create different VLANs if
we actually want them to have that.

199
00:10:53.800 --> 00:10:59.300
And a user then could actually be on
VLAN 20 over here in the cafeteria.

200
00:10:59.300 --> 00:11:04.061
And then roam across to the auditorium,
go all the way across the library, and

201
00:11:04.061 --> 00:11:06.169
still connect and be on VLAN 20.

202

episodes.description: This show begins with Ronnie and Cherokee explaining the double entendre of Data Loss. From a security standpoint we see this term being used to describe a data breach. From a networking standpoint data loss takes on a new meaning, literally loosing or dropping packets across your network. 00:26:21.970 --> 00:26:23.940
what does each one bring to us?

504
00:26:23.940 --> 00:26:28.170
Whereas the idea of the weighting gives
us, how do we actually prioritize?

505
00:26:28.170 --> 00:26:29.620
I think I'm saying all those backwards.

506
00:26:29.620 --> 00:26:31.120
In my mind it made sense.

507
00:26:32.230 --> 00:26:33.805
So let me make sure.

508
00:26:33.805 --> 00:26:39.480
Weighting allows us to, yeah, to kind of
give an assessment of every single one and

509
00:26:39.480 --> 00:26:41.630
then put that into the priority.

510
00:26:41.630 --> 00:26:44.980
And then the assessment gives us
that ability to evaluate each one.

511
00:26:44.980 --> 00:26:48.060
And then, say all right,
here's what each one actually means.

512
00:26:48.060 --> 00:26:50.820
And then we put it into the weight
system and do what we need to.

513
00:26:50.820 --> 00:26:53.030
So it's kind of funky.

514
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:54.717
They both mean very similar.

515
00:26:54.717 --> 00:26:57.244
>> Yeah.
>> But they are just slightly different,

516
00:26:57.244 --> 00:26:58.440
not much though.

517
00:26:58.440 --> 00:27:02.383
>> All right, well, Ronnie, we have
gone down a laundry list of terms and

518
00:27:02.383 --> 00:27:06.820
vocabulary and ideas and concepts that
our good viewers out there need to know.

519
00:27:06.820 --> 00:27:09.390
But we've finally come to the end,
and it was perfect timing, too.

520
00:27:09.390 --> 00:27:12.500
Our clock is ticking down to
the last tock for this episode.

521
00:27:12.500 --> 00:27:16.040
So Ronnie, thank you so much for dropping
by, explaining these terms for us so

522
00:27:16.040 --> 00:27:17.120
that we'll know them.

523
00:27:17.120 --> 00:27:18.120
And thank you for watching.

524
00:27:18.120 --> 00:27:20.170
But like I said,
it's time for us to sign off.

525
00:27:20.170 --> 00:27:22.490
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

526
00:27:22.490 --> 00:27:23.350
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

527
00:27:23.350 --> 00:27:24.583
>> And we'll see you next time.

528
00:27:26.279 --> 00:27:32.128
[MUSIC]

529
00:27:32.128 --> 00:27:35.304
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike compare and contrast different access control models. They look at discretionary access control, mandatory access control, as well as nondiscretionary access control.
episodes.title: Understand Access Control Models
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.580 --> 00:00:08.230
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.230 --> 00:00:12.410
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.410 --> 00:00:16.605
>> Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV, I'm your host

4
00:00:16.605 --> 00:00:21.360
Mike Rodrick and today we're doing
our Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals.

5
00:00:21.360 --> 00:00:25.113
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at security models and

6
00:00:25.113 --> 00:00:28.243
making sure we understand more
of access control models.

7
00:00:28.243 --> 00:00:31.302
And here to explain this to us is
the master of all things Cisco,

8
00:00:31.302 --> 00:00:33.742
Mister Ronnie Wong,
how you doing today Ronnie.

9
00:00:33.742 --> 00:00:36.010
>> Well thank you for
having me back on the show Mike.

10
00:00:36.010 --> 00:00:40.520
And thank you for standing in for Cherokee
as we continue through our series here.

11
00:00:40.520 --> 00:00:44.680
What we're taking a look at today is of
course different access control models and

12
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:48.540
this is an important part of technical
control that we have to make sure that we

13
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:53.210
understand and we implement as we start
to learn more and more about security.

14
00:00:53.210 --> 00:00:57.840
It's always neat to think about
some of the different tools and

15
00:00:57.840 --> 00:00:59.380
devices that are out there.

16
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:02.160
Some of the security concepts
that we can talk about.

17
00:01:02.160 --> 00:01:04.010
But when it comes down to it, meat and

18
00:01:04.010 --> 00:01:08.010
potatoes security it really boils down to
access control a lot of times, right Mike?

19
00:01:08.010 --> 00:01:11.630
>> It really does, yeah that is one of the
things that I think as admins if anything

20
00:01:11.630 --> 00:01:13.890
we've really spent a lot of time on.

21
00:01:13.890 --> 00:01:16.460
Is making sure that the right people
have access to what they need and

22
00:01:16.460 --> 00:01:18.610
the wrong people don't have access.

23
00:01:18.610 --> 00:01:22.160
Now when we talk access control here,
Ronnie we're really not talking about

24
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:25.860
Physical security,
more about security of information.

25
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:27.360
>> A lot of times, yes.

26
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:31.910
The very fact that we have to be
able to protect our information, but

27
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:35.610
that as well as even access into
our physical location, I guess.

28
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:40.010
We could even talk about physical access
in that way but a lot of times when it

29
00:01:40.010 --> 00:01:44.020
comes down to it, there's really three
models that we have to be familiar with,

30
00:01:44.020 --> 00:01:47.240
when it comes down to data protection,
is what we're really facing.

31
00:01:47.240 --> 00:01:49.720
>> All right, so what's the first
model we wanna look at today?

32
00:01:49.720 --> 00:01:53.330
>> Well, the first one of course actually,
is kinda neat and descriptive right?

33
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:57.430
Is the idea of what we call
the Discretionary Access Control model.

34
00:01:57.430 --> 00:02:01.300
So as we break that down,
as far as those terms go.

35
00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:04.070
The term discretionary is probably
the only term that we may not

36
00:02:04.070 --> 00:02:05.140
be as familiar with.

37
00:02:05.140 --> 00:02:06.630
Access control makes sense.

38
00:02:06.630 --> 00:02:09.191
You can get access, or
we're limiting your access.

39
00:02:09.191 --> 00:02:14.169
But the term discretionary is probably
where most people tend to fall apart

40
00:02:14.169 --> 00:02:18.198
on this and when like what does
that mean when we start talking

41
00:02:18.198 --> 00:02:21.531
about the idea of
discretionary access control.

42
00:02:21.531 --> 00:02:25.600
And the first time that I start hear about
like if I'm going to be discreet about

43
00:02:25.600 --> 00:02:29.116
something, hidden access is that
what I'm really talking about or

44
00:02:29.116 --> 00:02:32.466
trying to slide underneath the radar
in terms of my control but.

45
00:02:32.466 --> 00:02:33.910
>> That's not really it, is it?

46
00:02:33.910 --> 00:02:38.077
>> That's really not it, and I always try
to find analogies to things that I would

47
00:02:38.077 --> 00:02:40.111
have understood a little bit better.

48
00:02:40.111 --> 00:02:44.387
And the one that always kind of got
me is that when I started reading and

49
00:02:44.387 --> 00:02:48.812
learning about this is, I always
think about some movie scene, Mike,

50
00:02:48.812 --> 00:02:52.502
where there's the bouncer's
standing at the front door of

51
00:02:52.502 --> 00:02:56.168
the cool nightclub that
everybody's trying to get into.

52
00:02:56.168 --> 00:02:59.912
And he's standing there and he's allowing
for certain people to come in and,

53
00:02:59.912 --> 00:03:04.390
of course, somebody always walked up the
front door and they get in but you can't.

54
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:08.000
And so the more that I started thinking
about that, the more I said, that sounds

55
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:11.510
more like the discretionary access control
as I read about it in terms of security.

56
00:03:11.510 --> 00:03:15.990
That a single individual or
administrator can pretty much create

57
00:03:15.990 --> 00:03:20.400
a list of who can get in,
and who can't get in but

58
00:03:20.400 --> 00:03:23.760
as well as what privileges
are also allowed to do so as well.

59
00:03:23.760 --> 00:03:27.790
So usually that's the kind of
associations I think about.

60
00:03:27.790 --> 00:03:29.680
So Mike is that pretty good or is that.

61
00:03:29.680 --> 00:03:32.750
>> I like that, I like that analogy.

62
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:36.630
In my mind I always think of
discretionary access control well it's at

63
00:03:36.630 --> 00:03:39.280
the owners of
the information's discretion.

64
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:42.030
And when we say it's discretion,
we're talking about,

65
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:45.830
it's your decision who does or
doesn't have access.

66
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:50.190
So, discretionary access control,
it's at the discretion of the owner of

67
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:52.890
the information who should or
should not have access.

68
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:55.380
And like you said, it's simply a list.

69
00:03:55.380 --> 00:03:59.500
Now Ronnie, I know so
if you put me on that list you

70
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:03.960
can assign me the different permissions
as to what level of access i have.

71
00:04:03.960 --> 00:04:08.130
>> Right, so with not only
deciding who can gain access in,

72
00:04:08.130 --> 00:04:11.290
especially with the technical controls
that we're normally talking about.

73
00:04:11.290 --> 00:04:15.540
We can even limit amount of access even
though we might have two different people

74
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:19.010
access on the same of
a place if we talk about.

75
00:04:19.010 --> 00:04:20.980
So let's go and take a look at my screen.

76
00:04:20.980 --> 00:04:22.970
Hopefully this will
help us to demonstrate.

77
00:04:22.970 --> 00:04:27.170
Now what I'm really just talking about, of
course, is just using file permissions as

78
00:04:27.170 --> 00:04:32.810
a good description or a good example
of discretionary access control.

79
00:04:32.810 --> 00:04:34.520
If this exists on my machine,

80
00:04:34.520 --> 00:04:38.880
I'm the one that really kind of
says who gets access to what.

81
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:44.100
So at the very top here, level that
I may have I may say I've created

82
00:04:44.100 --> 00:04:49.230
a network folder and inside of that folder
I've created two sub folder inside of it.

83
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:52.160
One for my configs and the other one
of course for list of devices or

84
00:04:52.160 --> 00:04:54.460
whatever it might be that I have.

85
00:04:54.460 --> 00:04:59.050
Now at this point I can assign my self or
an individual called Ronnie and

86
00:04:59.050 --> 00:05:02.530
actually give them the amount
of access that they need.

87
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:06.064
So for Ronnie I may say look
he has read permissions.

88
00:05:06.064 --> 00:05:09.980
Allows him to be able to look inside
it but really not do anything else to

89
00:05:09.980 --> 00:05:14.430
change anything within that folder but
it really just allows him to do so.

90
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:16.489
But Mike I give read and execute.

91
00:05:16.489 --> 00:05:19.090
So if there's any executable files
in there he can run those too.

92
00:05:19.090 --> 00:05:21.600
>> [SOUND]
>> Yeah that's right, and

93
00:05:21.600 --> 00:05:24.028
that may not be the best thing
in the world for me to do, so

94
00:05:24.028 --> 00:05:26.061
I may actually wanna
change that a little bit.

95
00:05:26.061 --> 00:05:26.870
>> [LAUGH].

96
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:28.740
>> But if I do that that's perfectly fine.

97
00:05:28.740 --> 00:05:34.310
It allows us to say that now anybody else
who is not on this list Mike though,

98
00:05:34.310 --> 00:05:35.250
what happens here?

99
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:36.580
>> Well, that was my next question Ronnie.

100
00:05:36.580 --> 00:05:41.967
You're talking about that analogy with
the bouncer at a nightclub for example.

101
00:05:41.967 --> 00:05:46.386
If I go up to that bouncer and I'm on
the list he can allow me to come in.

102
00:05:46.386 --> 00:05:48.740
But what happens when I'm not on the list?

103
00:05:48.740 --> 00:05:49.655
Then what does the bouncer do?

104
00:05:49.655 --> 00:05:52.476
>> Yeah, if you're not on the list,
you're not gonna get in.

105
00:05:52.476 --> 00:05:56.025
So normally,
we talk about an implicit type of deny, so

106
00:05:56.025 --> 00:06:01.410
that if you're not there, that's what
should normally end up happening.

107
00:06:01.410 --> 00:06:03.150
Now, along with this, of course,

108
00:06:03.150 --> 00:06:06.150
this would be impossible
on a real regular basis,

109
00:06:06.150 --> 00:06:10.500
if we had to set up these permissions for
every single substructure that's in there.

110
00:06:10.500 --> 00:06:13.600
So here I just have folders, but
Mike if there's 1,000 files inside,

111
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:16.450
and I have to do this for
every single one of those.

112
00:06:16.450 --> 00:06:17.259
>> Times hundreds or
thousands of employees.

113
00:06:17.259 --> 00:06:18.924
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

114
00:06:18.924 --> 00:06:23.348
>> It becomes a little bit harder to
think about and to even want to do.

115
00:06:23.348 --> 00:06:27.190
So the great thing is most of this,
once we apply at it at the upper level,

116
00:06:27.190 --> 00:06:31.250
it tends to trickle down or
we get what we call of course inheritance.

117
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:35.970
And so here when I go into
the Configs folder, I can see and

118
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:38.660
I've kinda grayed it out, and this is the
way that you normally see about Microsoft

119
00:06:38.660 --> 00:06:41.920
systems where it's kinda grayed out
a little bit, you don't tend to change it.

120
00:06:41.920 --> 00:06:46.570
But like Mike here, he ended up having the
permissions allow Read & Execute up here.

121
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:48.950
But in the config,
he has the same permissions.

122
00:06:48.950 --> 00:06:53.310
This is without having to go in there and
actually make a new list for

123
00:06:53.310 --> 00:06:55.510
the configs folder to do so.

124
00:06:55.510 --> 00:06:59.227
But I can go ahead and reassign
Ronnie's permissions if we wanted to,

125
00:06:59.227 --> 00:07:03.259
to explicitly give him new permission,
I didn't do that at this point, but

126
00:07:03.259 --> 00:07:04.655
I could do that right now.

127
00:07:04.655 --> 00:07:08.873
So let's say that here, we'll go deny.

128
00:07:08.873 --> 00:07:12.310
Okay, and now we might find nothing.

129
00:07:12.310 --> 00:07:14.780
Ronnie can look at the network folder.

130
00:07:14.780 --> 00:07:16.610
But when it comes down
to the config folder,

131
00:07:16.610 --> 00:07:19.660
he's not gonna be able to
read into that folder either.

132
00:07:19.660 --> 00:07:23.060
So now, we can control that on
a granular basis if we need to.

133
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:26.400
But if we don't I've just inherit
all those other permissions.

134
00:07:26.400 --> 00:07:28.930
And here I just showed the same
thing down here at the bottom.

135
00:07:28.930 --> 00:07:31.600
Being able to change those
permissions as well.

136
00:07:31.600 --> 00:07:36.090
So it gives us, like what Mike was
talking about, the owner's discretion.

137
00:07:36.090 --> 00:07:37.580
Who he chooses.

138
00:07:37.580 --> 00:07:41.095
So when it comes down to it's based
on what the administrator choose or

139
00:07:41.095 --> 00:07:43.956
who the administrator chooses and
what level of access or

140
00:07:43.956 --> 00:07:46.056
what level of control that we want to set.

141
00:07:46.056 --> 00:07:49.270
So it's really good,
because we don't wanna have to create,

142
00:07:49.270 --> 00:07:53.091
if we didn't do this, right Mike, and
I still need these different ones,

143
00:07:53.091 --> 00:07:56.451
I need a different folder for, so
there might be Ronnie configs.

144
00:07:56.451 --> 00:08:00.365
And then Mike configs, and then one for
Ronnie devices and Mike devices and

145
00:08:00.365 --> 00:08:02.609
It would get out of hand really quickly.

146
00:08:02.609 --> 00:08:05.726
>> Yeah, administrative overhead
would just drive you crazy and

147
00:08:05.726 --> 00:08:09.548
that's why we love taking advantage of
inheritance that most systems that do

148
00:08:09.548 --> 00:08:11.754
discretionary access control will allow.

149
00:08:11.754 --> 00:08:15.859
You set it once at the highest level that
you can and let those formations inherit

150
00:08:15.859 --> 00:08:20.340
down to the objects inside, that makes
it really easy to manage as an admin.

151
00:08:20.340 --> 00:08:22.540
>> Now why does this
matter to cyber security,

152
00:08:22.540 --> 00:08:24.540
that's what we really
have to think about here.

153
00:08:24.540 --> 00:08:26.050
It's fairly simple.

154
00:08:26.050 --> 00:08:29.960
I know that for me,
when I first started studying and

155
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:33.860
trying to say, I think security's kind of
a focus that I'd really like to understand

156
00:08:33.860 --> 00:08:38.530
a little bit more, it was really
having to understand this model first.

157
00:08:38.530 --> 00:08:42.250
And if there's anything that's really
confusing, once you start getting into

158
00:08:42.250 --> 00:08:45.380
the permissions, and
what happens when they apply here, and

159
00:08:45.380 --> 00:08:48.040
they don't apply here, and
trying to figure that out.

160
00:08:48.040 --> 00:08:50.570
So you need to have a good
solid understanding of that,

161
00:08:50.570 --> 00:08:55.080
on existing structures that you
are going to have to monitor, if you

162
00:08:55.080 --> 00:08:58.718
want to actually understand the overall
effective permissions that somebody has.

163
00:08:58.718 --> 00:09:01.520
Or you might be wondering
at the end of the day,

164
00:09:01.520 --> 00:09:04.830
why is it that Mike has access
to something but Ronnie doesn't?

165
00:09:04.830 --> 00:09:06.940
And you really need to able
to trace that thing out.

166
00:09:06.940 --> 00:09:10.990
So discretion access control, one of the
topics that you really need to make sure

167
00:09:10.990 --> 00:09:15.550
that you have a solid, at least
fundamental overall understanding of.

168
00:09:15.550 --> 00:09:19.100
But in reality, especially as a network
admin, you need to make sure.

169
00:09:19.100 --> 00:09:22.470
Because availability,
part of the CIA triangle,

170
00:09:22.470 --> 00:09:26.470
this is where the rubber hits the road
again is that idea of availability, and

171
00:09:26.470 --> 00:09:29.080
that's really a key function
that we have to make sure of.

172
00:09:29.080 --> 00:09:32.050
We can't restrict it too much but at
the same time they need to be available to

173
00:09:32.050 --> 00:09:36.730
the authorized resources without being
available to unauthorized resources.

174
00:09:36.730 --> 00:09:38.090
Discretionary is one of
the ways to do this.

175
00:09:38.090 --> 00:09:42.330
>> Absolutely it's definitely something
that we're troubleshooting all the time

176
00:09:42.330 --> 00:09:44.930
because people call up and
say hey I don't have access to this and

177
00:09:44.930 --> 00:09:46.720
I think I should have access.

178
00:09:46.720 --> 00:09:50.400
And then we go in and we have to look at
the permissions that have been signed,

179
00:09:50.400 --> 00:09:52.010
how they're inheriting,
whether they've been blocked,

180
00:09:52.010 --> 00:09:55.460
whether there's opposite permissions
that have been signed at some point.

181
00:09:55.460 --> 00:09:57.660
And then worrying about
the implicit deny and

182
00:09:57.660 --> 00:10:00.600
explicit denies,
always a challenge as well.

183
00:10:00.600 --> 00:10:02.410
Now Ronnie,
we said there were three models, so

184
00:10:02.410 --> 00:10:05.710
discretionary access control
being model number one.

185
00:10:05.710 --> 00:10:07.830
What's the next one we
need to be familiar with?

186
00:10:07.830 --> 00:10:13.410
>> The next one is probably the one that
more people in general are familiar with.

187
00:10:13.410 --> 00:10:17.450
And that's due to the popularization of
movies, again, more that anything else.

188
00:10:17.450 --> 00:10:22.330
If you watched Mission Impossible movies
or any type of spy movie, inevitably,

189
00:10:22.330 --> 00:10:25.870
there shows up a folder and
on that folder, there's a big gigantic,

190
00:10:25.870 --> 00:10:27.400
red imprint on it.

191
00:10:27.400 --> 00:10:32.080
And it says, top secret or
eyes only or whatever it is, right?

192
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:36.058
And what is that actually saying and
meaning there?

193
00:10:36.058 --> 00:10:41.000
Well they're pretty much saying that hey,
here is a particular level of clearance

194

00:22:01.340 --> 00:22:05.342
That model we also have the model for
our mandatory access control.

424
00:22:05.342 --> 00:22:07.000
What does that leave us, Ronnie?

425
00:22:07.000 --> 00:22:07.820
I know there's one more.

426
00:22:07.820 --> 00:22:09.118
>> Yeah, there is one more,
which is strange.

427
00:22:09.118 --> 00:22:13.430
It's the opposite of discretionary,
non-discretionary access control.

428
00:22:13.430 --> 00:22:18.250
Now this one always threw me,
because it really took me just a moment,

429
00:22:18.250 --> 00:22:21.990
at the beginning when I started
understanding permissions, right?

430
00:22:21.990 --> 00:22:23.890
I said okay, so that's discretionary.

431
00:22:23.890 --> 00:22:27.170
But then when it comes down to
non-discretion access control, this is

432
00:22:27.170 --> 00:22:31.400
where we use a system in place that's
actually gonna be the same for everyone.

433
00:22:31.400 --> 00:22:34.200
Regardless of their
particular permissions,

434
00:22:34.200 --> 00:22:35.480
they're still using the same system.

435
00:22:35.480 --> 00:22:39.100
So it's generic or
what we call global in its scope.

436
00:22:39.100 --> 00:22:42.589
Normally, it's based on a system of
either rules that are in place or

437
00:22:42.589 --> 00:22:45.547
the idea of course,
of different roles that are in place.

438
00:22:45.547 --> 00:22:49.020
So for
example let's take a look at my diagram.

439
00:22:49.020 --> 00:22:50.853
I'm was gonna say let me
give you two examples but

440
00:22:50.853 --> 00:22:52.744
showing you the diagram
is probably easier okay.

441
00:22:52.744 --> 00:22:55.050
If we take an example of a Firewall.

442
00:22:55.050 --> 00:23:00.560
This is a non-discretionary access control
type of system that we can have in place.

443
00:23:00.560 --> 00:23:03.470
Every package that passes through that
Firewall, it has to go through that

444
00:23:03.470 --> 00:23:06.930
firewall and it has to go through
the rules that are in place.

445
00:23:06.930 --> 00:23:10.760
It doesn't matter if this is
Mike's data or Ronnie's data.

446
00:23:10.760 --> 00:23:11.380
It has to go through.

447
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:15.930
Mike's data doesn't say hey, this is me,
I'm gonna go around the firewall and

448
00:23:15.930 --> 00:23:17.530
just do that instead.

449
00:23:17.530 --> 00:23:20.390
It has to be there, it has to go through.

450
00:23:20.390 --> 00:23:24.080
So that's what makes it mandatory,
or non-discretionary.

451
00:23:24.080 --> 00:23:27.660
It's the same set of rules
that our data goes through.

452
00:23:27.660 --> 00:23:30.560
So, not based on individuals' wish or
desires, or

453
00:23:30.560 --> 00:23:33.560
even of clearance level,
it still has to go through there.

454
00:23:33.560 --> 00:23:36.120
The other part is if Mike and

455
00:23:36.120 --> 00:23:40.050
I do have machines on the same
Active Directory Network.

456
00:23:40.050 --> 00:23:45.075
Even if Mike is president of the company
and I'm just the janitor of the company.

457
00:23:45.075 --> 00:23:48.420
Well when it comes down to logging
on to an Active Directory joined

458
00:23:48.420 --> 00:23:50.520
machine, guess what?

459
00:23:50.520 --> 00:23:52.050
We're still logging on, guess what?

460
00:23:52.050 --> 00:23:53.778
One Active Directory.

461
00:23:53.778 --> 00:23:57.834
So, Mike gives him a ton more of
privileges than what Ronnie the janitor

462
00:23:57.834 --> 00:24:00.471
has Same time it's still
not discretionary,

463
00:24:00.471 --> 00:24:04.740
it's saying everybody's using
the active directory system.

464
00:24:04.740 --> 00:24:10.460
So one is based on roles,
the firewall here is based on rules.

465
00:24:10.460 --> 00:24:13.250
So that way it does make it
non-discretionary, where were saying hey,

466
00:24:13.250 --> 00:24:15.040
there's rules and the roles here.

467
00:24:15.040 --> 00:24:21.760
Discretionary says hey, Mike says I don't
like running so much, read or deny.

468
00:24:21.760 --> 00:24:24.240
And that's the system that we have.

469
00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:28.120
But each of these is very
important because one,

470
00:24:28.120 --> 00:24:29.280
if you take a look at them, right.

471
00:24:29.280 --> 00:24:33.270
The idea of this non-discretionary,
right, is really implementing

472
00:24:33.270 --> 00:24:38.200
the hard set type of controls that we
want to make sure everybody goes through.

473
00:24:38.200 --> 00:24:41.390
The discretionary gives us
that ability to be granular at

474
00:24:41.390 --> 00:24:44.270
how much do we want
somebody to get access to.

475
00:24:44.270 --> 00:24:48.280
The mandatory allows us to set
classification levels of what do

476
00:24:48.280 --> 00:24:51.230
we really want them to
get access to as well.

477
00:24:51.230 --> 00:24:54.040
And that way we can control
it in that way too.

478
00:24:54.040 --> 00:24:57.700
So all these kind of really give
us an overall security function

479
00:24:57.700 --> 00:25:00.930
that really helps us to protect in
that CIA triangle everything but

480
00:25:00.930 --> 00:25:02.950
really focusing in on the availability.

481
00:25:02.950 --> 00:25:06.631
>> Absolutely and when we first started
this we said there were three models and

482
00:25:06.631 --> 00:25:08.360
I know some of us might
have been thinking,

483
00:25:08.360 --> 00:25:12.660
well, I wonder which one
we use in our organization.

484
00:25:12.660 --> 00:25:16.090
And when it comes down to it,
there's a good chance that you're using

485
00:25:16.090 --> 00:25:19.440
more than one, if not all of these,
depending on where you're looking.

486
00:25:19.440 --> 00:25:24.940
You're probably using mandatory access
control, maybe, on certain documents.

487
00:25:24.940 --> 00:25:26.790
Or you're using discretionary
access control for

488
00:25:26.790 --> 00:25:31.392
your file system, but non-discretionary
on your routers and on your firewalls.

489
00:25:31.392 --> 00:25:34.850
>> Yeah and so placement is also
key in defending network, and

490
00:25:34.850 --> 00:25:37.540
we talked about defense in
depth in an earlier episode,

491
00:25:37.540 --> 00:25:41.840
in this particular section as
we covered it, is that idea.

492
00:25:41.840 --> 00:25:44.920
Is that you'll probably see that that's
what's happening, even if there's not some

493
00:25:44.920 --> 00:25:48.910
formal security system there may be
certain documents where we go, yeah,

494
00:25:48.910 --> 00:25:50.450
we don't let that out to everybody.

495
00:25:50.450 --> 00:25:55.080
And then, you're essentially kind of, even
in your mind, saying that's top secret.

496
00:25:55.080 --> 00:25:58.650
>> You're basically classifying it,
even if you don't have a formal system,

497
00:25:58.650 --> 00:26:01.260
you are still going through some type
of classification of that information.

498
00:26:01.260 --> 00:26:02.446
>> Yeah, and that's helps too.

499
00:26:02.446 --> 00:26:04.996
And then making sure of just basic
protection, like what you're saying,

500
00:26:04.996 --> 00:26:05.687
that the firewall.

501
00:26:05.687 --> 00:26:10.316
And then, for access into our systems,
we generally have the ability to have all

502
00:26:10.316 --> 00:26:14.538
that, as far as an active directory
network or some type of login system,

503
00:26:14.538 --> 00:26:17.245
where it may be centralized in that way,
too.

504
00:26:17.245 --> 00:26:21.920
So all these are great models and we've
given you a couple of different examples

505
00:26:21.920 --> 00:26:23.740
and talked about them quite a bit.

506
00:26:23.740 --> 00:26:27.850
But you really have to be familiar with
all of them as you continue going.

507
00:26:27.850 --> 00:26:32.220
And so you're going towards more advanced
certifications, learning these models and

508
00:26:32.220 --> 00:26:37.520
the depth that they can go into is
really going to be the key here.

509
00:26:37.520 --> 00:26:40.230
>> All right,
Ronnie great look there at those different

510
00:26:40.230 --> 00:26:42.480
access control models that
we need to be familiar with,

511
00:26:42.480 --> 00:26:46.560
discretionary, mandatory as
well as non-discretionary.

512
00:26:46.560 --> 00:26:47.730
So we appreciate that Ronnie.

513
00:26:47.730 --> 00:26:50.700
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

514
00:26:50.700 --> 00:26:53.800
Signing of for ITPRO TV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

515
00:26:53.800 --> 00:26:54.880
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

516
00:26:54.880 --> 00:26:56.428
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike define several industry standard terms relating to security. They look at network and host-based antivirus, and agent-based versus agentless protection. They also talk about log collection and SIEM systems.

1

I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals.

7

In this episode,

9

We've already spent,

00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:42.150

15

And now we have to move into well kind

16
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:49.510
Most of us when we first enter

00:00:49.510 --> 00:00:52.180

the more that I get into the realm of

00:01:04.554 --> 00:01:09.340
the more that I realize it's really more

the people that are in the field, or doing
the actual work and on the front line,

00:01:17.820 --> 00:01:21.850
if you're not talking the same language,

00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:26.610
It becomes really difficult to discuss
problems that you're having, or things or

00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:30.690
plans you want to implement, and
what we need to do to better protect our

00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:34.375
environment, our data and
our organization and our networks.

30
00:01:34.375 --> 00:01:38.205
It is very important that even on the
admin side of things, we are familiar with

31
00:01:38.205 --> 00:01:42.120
the terms and we understand the lingo,
if you will, of security.

32
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:44.690
>> Yeah, so a great place for
us to actually take a look at this, then,

33
00:01:44.690 --> 00:01:47.820
is to contrast a couple
of different terms.

34
00:01:47.820 --> 00:01:51.600
And we're gonna kind of do six
different terms we're gonna contrast,

35
00:01:51.600 --> 00:01:53.744
just two at a time, against each other.

36
00:01:53.744 --> 00:01:57.728
And it's so that we understand what we're
really talking about and that we have,

37
00:01:57.728 --> 00:02:00.670
cuz If not, you may be talking
about something to someone and

38
00:02:00.670 --> 00:02:03.753
they may not understand what
you're actually talking about.

39
00:02:03.753 --> 00:02:06.150
And they may be thinking
another concept and

40
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:10.488
one of the first concepts we really wanted
to make sure that we address is gonna be

41
00:02:10.488 --> 00:02:13.520
in the realm of anti virus
more than anything else.

42
00:02:13.520 --> 00:02:16.055
Now, Mike,
when you think about anti virus,

43
00:02:16.055 --> 00:02:19.305
let's not even put in our
network administration hat yet.

44
00:02:19.305 --> 00:02:22.555
When you think about anti virus, what do
you normally think about when you say

45
00:02:22.555 --> 00:02:24.670
somebody needs antivirus
on their computer?

46
00:02:24.670 --> 00:02:28.030
>> Well I think about just going and
getting the media and installing it

47
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:32.650
locally on that machine so that'll protect
that one machine hopefully from Malware.

48
00:02:32.650 --> 00:02:35.370
>> Yeah, that's exactly what I think
about anytime somebody says, hey,

49
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:37.445
what do I need to do to
protect my computer at home?

50
00:02:37.445 --> 00:02:41.150
I'm like, hey, you need to download
an antivirus program at home.

51
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:43.680
Just go out to the iInternet and
make sure you download a free one, and

52
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:47.430
I might make a recommendation or two
about which ones that I really like and

53
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:48.830
have used in the past.

54
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:51.170
And that's normally what we think about.

55
00:02:51.170 --> 00:02:55.230
But now when we get into
the realm of managing a network,

56
00:02:55.230 --> 00:03:00.360
we're really not talking about that a lot
of times, as far as just making sure that

57
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.890
user has antivirus on his computer and
making sure they do that.

58
00:03:05.890 --> 00:03:09.540
We're really talking about making sure,
what, that we have good coverage

59
00:03:09.540 --> 00:03:13.780
of antivirus protection throughout
our entire network as well.

60
00:03:13.780 --> 00:03:17.560
So there comes a contrast when
you start hearing two terms here.

61
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:21.564
The network antivirus and
of course the host antivirus.

62
00:03:21.564 --> 00:03:26.236
And the one that we just described of
course is the host antivirus where it's

63
00:03:26.236 --> 00:03:28.574
really on every individual machine.

64
00:03:28.574 --> 00:03:33.377
And that's kind of where we like to see
the end result being, but now we also need

65
00:03:33.377 --> 00:03:37.860
to just compare it against the idea
of the network antivirus as well.

66
00:03:37.860 --> 00:03:40.440
They both do the same thing, right?

67
00:03:40.440 --> 00:03:43.010
The same thing that
an antivirus really does.

68
00:03:43.010 --> 00:03:47.910
It allows you to be able to take files and
examine those files, and find it for

69
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:51.410
some type of malicious software or
a pattern that it's looking for

70
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:55.020
to match up against as far
as signature definitions.

71
00:03:55.020 --> 00:03:58.530
But in terms of both of them,
they do that.

72
00:03:58.530 --> 00:03:59.768
And this is kinda the key.

73
00:03:59.768 --> 00:04:01.220
>> Absolutely.

74
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:02.700
I know for a long time, we've run,

75
00:04:02.700 --> 00:04:06.190
we've understood the importance of running
antivirus on every single machine.

76
00:04:06.190 --> 00:04:11.102
That host-based antivirus,
most organizations implement that.

77
00:04:11.102 --> 00:04:15.560
But we have to keep in mind,
it does protect just that one machine.

78
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:21.443
And what was happening is, let's say we
get a worm or something on our system.

79
00:04:21.443 --> 00:04:24.777
There's nothing stopping that from
traveling around the network and

80
00:04:24.777 --> 00:04:28.402
looking for that one host that maybe
somebody has turned the antivirus off.

81
00:04:28.402 --> 00:04:31.390
You know or
hasn't updated their latest definitions.

82
00:04:31.390 --> 00:04:32.600
There's nothing stopping that.

83
00:04:32.600 --> 00:04:38.469
Each host is protected that's running the
antivirus, but the network itself is not.

84
00:04:38.469 --> 00:04:39.980
And that was kind of silly.

85
00:04:39.980 --> 00:04:43.810
Why let it run around on the network
looking for a vulnerable host?

86
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:45.260
Let's do it at both, let's look for

87
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:49.100
let's run antivirus on the host,
as well as at the network level.

88
00:04:49.100 --> 00:04:54.080
>> And this is where most of us as we're
entering into this cyber security world,

89
00:04:54.080 --> 00:04:55.920
where we might get the confusion right.

90
00:04:55.920 --> 00:04:58.730
The very fact somebody may be
addressing the idea of the host, but

91
00:04:58.730 --> 00:05:01.330
then you might have a security
administrator that's really talking about

92
00:05:01.330 --> 00:05:05.300
that idea of network based
types of antivirus as well.

93
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:09.291
And there's really a couple of different
ones even at this network level that you

94
00:05:09.291 --> 00:05:10.239
can talk about to.

95
00:05:10.239 --> 00:05:14.798
One is the idea that the management of
the anti virus, the deployment of it,

96
00:05:14.798 --> 00:05:19.501
making sure that every machine has it,
but also of course constantly scanning

97
00:05:19.501 --> 00:05:24.060
the entire network for
something that is traveling like that.

98
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:28.944
Also at that particular end of
the network antivirus is that ability to

99
00:05:28.944 --> 00:05:33.354
monitor data or traffic that is
going in and out of our network.

100
00:05:33.354 --> 00:05:38.377
And being able to spot the same type of
anti or the same type of virus activity

101
00:05:38.377 --> 00:05:42.790
as it enters into the network and
as it leaves the network as well.

102
00:05:42.790 --> 00:05:45.130
So it can track it even at the perimeter.

103
00:05:45.130 --> 00:05:49.850
So both of them are good solutions that
we should have a good, firm grasp on.

104
00:05:49.850 --> 00:05:52.610
And most of the time,
especially as your network gets bigger,

105
00:05:52.610 --> 00:05:54.395
it should be implemented at that level.

106
00:05:54.395 --> 00:05:57.291
Even though you could say, well I'm
not worried about it so much Mike,

107
00:05:57.291 --> 00:05:59.770
because I know on every server,
I'm running an antivirus.

108
00:05:59.770 --> 00:06:03.140
I know on every single desktop,
I'm running this.

109
00:06:03.140 --> 00:06:06.220
But the very fact that it's actually
travelling around in your network just

110
00:06:06.220 --> 00:06:11.450
waiting means there is a potential
aspect of this where it

111
00:06:11.450 --> 00:06:15.070
could infect a host before the antivirus
has a chance to turn on and do anything.

112
00:06:15.070 --> 00:06:15.880
>> Absolutely.

113
00:06:15.880 --> 00:06:19.210
An analogy you might
use to describe this is

114
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:21.350
is think about an office building right?

115
00:06:21.350 --> 00:06:25.450
Each one of the offices in my
building has a door, has a lock.

116
00:06:25.450 --> 00:06:29.280
So I can lock my office,
Ronnie can lock his office.

117
00:06:29.280 --> 00:06:32.990
But we don't leave the front door to
the building itself wide open, right?

118
00:06:32.990 --> 00:06:34.630
We lock that as well.

119
00:06:34.630 --> 00:06:37.500
So you can look at the locks
on the individual offices

120
00:06:37.500 --> 00:06:41.820
as the host-based type antivirus,
protecting the individual office.

121
00:06:41.820 --> 00:06:45.400
But then the building as a whole is
also protected with that front door and

122
00:06:45.400 --> 00:06:47.570
the lock and
the guard that I've placed there.

123
00:06:47.570 --> 00:06:50.950
Then that's kind of like
my network based antivirus.

124
00:06:50.950 --> 00:06:52.720
Let's not only protect each office but

125
00:06:52.720 --> 00:06:57.500
let's protect the corridors that
travel between the offices.

126
00:06:57.500 --> 00:06:59.060
>> And it really is about that right.

127
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:00.730
The more pathways that we allow for

interaction to actually run
in the background for us.

493
00:25:41.480 --> 00:25:43.480
And it can start at
the startup of a computer.

494
00:25:43.480 --> 00:25:46.740
But at the same time,
we can log out of the computer, and

495
00:25:46.740 --> 00:25:48.870
the process can still run by itself.

496
00:25:48.870 --> 00:25:53.030
Okay, and so it does really equal out to
the idea of what we would call a service

497
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:54.800
inside of Microsoft too.

498
00:25:54.800 --> 00:25:57.510
Where we can actually
have it run underneath,

499
00:25:57.510 --> 00:25:59.580
not the context of my user account.

500
00:25:59.580 --> 00:26:02.370
But it can run as a self or
a system account and

501
00:26:02.370 --> 00:26:06.190
still keep running even if I'm
logged off of the computer as well.

502
00:26:06.190 --> 00:26:10.813
So inside the Linux, Daemons are pretty
much we end up running entire servers,

503
00:26:10.813 --> 00:26:13.918
whereas in the Windows world,
we call them servers or

504
00:26:13.918 --> 00:26:16.144
services that run in the background.

505
00:26:16.144 --> 00:26:20.740
Most of these services are going to start
up when the computer starts up as well.

506
00:26:20.740 --> 00:26:23.150
So they don't need our
permission to start up.

507
00:26:23.150 --> 00:26:27.320
They start up when everything else in
the operating system starts up, too.

508
00:26:27.320 --> 00:26:31.470
Running in the background doesn't
need our interaction to do its job or

509
00:26:31.470 --> 00:26:32.610
to do anything.

510
00:26:32.610 --> 00:26:33.860
Sometimes, maybe at the beginning.

511
00:26:33.860 --> 00:26:36.540
It might require a configuration or
two but besides that,

512
00:26:36.540 --> 00:26:38.540
it knows how to do
everything it needs to do.

513
00:26:38.540 --> 00:26:39.190
Okay.

514
00:26:39.190 --> 00:26:43.280
So those are kind of the basic
Linux terms that we really have to

515
00:26:43.280 --> 00:26:45.840
make sure that we understand overall.

516
00:26:45.840 --> 00:26:51.130
Please do not take this as
being a full Linux on demo or

517
00:26:51.130 --> 00:26:53.210
tutorial, to get you up to speed on Linux,
it's not.

518
00:26:53.210 --> 00:26:56.170
If you wanna do that, check out our
Linux shows that we have available

519
00:26:56.170 --> 00:26:58.990
in our library, and
that one should be a better place.

520
00:26:58.990 --> 00:27:01.940
As far as cyber security goes,
understanding just a little bit of those

521
00:27:01.940 --> 00:27:04.900
concepts is really gonna get
you off on the right foot and

522
00:27:04.900 --> 00:27:06.520
get you prepared for the exam.

523
00:27:06.520 --> 00:27:08.954
>> Well, hasn't been a comprehensive
tutorial but Ron and

524
00:27:08.954 --> 00:27:11.245
I have looked at everything from forks,
fork bombs.

525
00:27:11.245 --> 00:27:14.512
We've looked at permissions,
we've looked at our,

526
00:27:14.512 --> 00:27:17.660
was it the sem-link and
then also our daemons.

527
00:27:17.660 --> 00:27:22.380
So hopefully, you guys can understand
those terms a little bit easier now.

528
00:27:22.380 --> 00:27:25.790
I think it's time to go ahead and
move on to our Windows terminology, so

529
00:27:25.790 --> 00:27:28.020
stay tuned and
that's what we'll be looking at next.

530
00:27:28.020 --> 00:27:29.900
So thank you for joining us today.

531
00:27:29.900 --> 00:27:31.630
And we're gonna go ahead and
wrap up for this show.

532
00:27:31.630 --> 00:27:33.870
Remember I'm your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

533
00:27:33.870 --> 00:27:34.610
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

534
00:27:34.610 --> 00:27:36.635
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

535

[MUSIC]
