>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This show Ronnie and Cherokee will explain what endpoint security means, what it does and the risk associated. Other tips are covered to help harden those individual endpoints.
episodes.title: Describe Endpoint Security Monitoring
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:05.375
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:05.375 --> 00:00:07.367
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.367 --> 00:00:08.472
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.472 --> 00:00:11.908
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.908 --> 00:00:15.410
>> Welcome to Your Cisco
cyber security series.

6
00:00:15.410 --> 00:00:17.550
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.550 --> 00:00:22.530
In this episode, we will be looking at how
to describe end point security monitoring.

8
00:00:22.530 --> 00:00:25.030
So if you think about this
concept of defense in depth,

9
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:28.175
we're not talking about devices on
the perimeter or edge of our network,

10
00:00:28.175 --> 00:00:30.535
we're really looking at
our individual endpoints.

11
00:00:30.535 --> 00:00:34.795
So, to help us explain this topic today,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong in studios.

12
00:00:34.795 --> 00:00:36.215
Thank you for joining us today, Ronnie.

13
00:00:36.215 --> 00:00:40.285
>> Well, thank you for having me back
as we continue on in our cyber security

14
00:00:40.285 --> 00:00:44.495
fundamentals and understanding
more about endpoint security,

15
00:00:44.495 --> 00:00:47.460
especially about monitoring
endpoint security.

16
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:49.650
A lot of times it's very easy for

17
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:54.180
a technician to think that we've got
everything under control as long as I know

18
00:00:54.180 --> 00:01:00.140
that my users are able to get access
to what they need on their computers,

19
00:01:00.140 --> 00:01:03.460
that they're not locked out of their
computer or out of their email.

20
00:01:03.460 --> 00:01:06.810
And as long as nobody's complaining,
we're perfectly fine.

21
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:10.630
But the very fact is, remember that
security attacks today, they normally

22
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:15.630
happen underneath the eye of the people
that are using the computer systems, and

23
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:18.420
they don't really know
what can be going on.

24
00:01:18.420 --> 00:01:23.050
If you can slip an email into
their inbox and make it something

25
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:27.185
that seems like they click on it,
it's very easy to get through all those

26
00:01:27.185 --> 00:01:32.230
different layers of security just by
doing some type of social engineering.

27
00:01:32.230 --> 00:01:36.960
Well, when we start looking into the realm
of cyber security, what we're also trying

28
00:01:36.960 --> 00:01:41.800
to do, of course, is be able to monitor
for situations, like that, as well as,

29
00:01:41.800 --> 00:01:44.890
of course, other things that
could compromise our systems and

30
00:01:44.890 --> 00:01:47.680
make sure that we
understand the focus here.

31
00:01:47.680 --> 00:01:51.559
In this particular level, right,
where we're talking about the fundamentals

32
00:01:51.559 --> 00:01:54.709
of cyber security,
we're starting with the endpoint devices.

33
00:01:54.709 --> 00:01:58.598
It doesn't mean that we don't
need protections on servers or

34
00:01:58.598 --> 00:02:04.057
on the network devices themselves, such
as routers, and switches, and firewalls,

35
00:02:04.057 --> 00:02:09.140
but it means that, hey, we need to also
monitor the endpoint security itself and

36
00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:11.870
that means we need to
know what to look for.

37
00:02:11.870 --> 00:02:14.198
>> Right.
>> We need to understand what is actually

38
00:02:14.198 --> 00:02:18.840
available at the end points for us that we
need to verify that are on and working or

39
00:02:18.840 --> 00:02:21.015
that we can pull information out of.

40
00:02:21.015 --> 00:02:25.202
So, we're gonna take a look at
several different ways that we

41
00:02:25.202 --> 00:02:29.320
can actually take a look at
the mechanisms that are in place.

42
00:02:29.320 --> 00:02:31.450
I can't even know the word
that I'm wanting to use,

43
00:02:31.450 --> 00:02:34.470
that will help us to find
out what is going on.

44
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:36.750
So, there's a whole list of them for
us to go through, and

45
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:38.000
that's what we're gonna do.

46
00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:42.154
>> Yeah, and talking about a list,
I see the first topic on that list is HID,

47
00:02:42.154 --> 00:02:43.772
host intrusion detection.

48
00:02:43.772 --> 00:02:45.020
What does that mean, Ronnie?

49
00:02:45.020 --> 00:02:47.850
>> When we start taking a look at
host intrusion detection right,

50
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:51.100
it is the idea of an intrusion
detection system.

51
00:02:51.100 --> 00:02:56.030
Regardless of whether it's host based or
whether it is network based, right?

52
00:02:56.030 --> 00:02:57.140
The very fact is,

53
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:03.170
we want to know when something has
actually got access into my system.

54
00:03:03.170 --> 00:03:07.670
And when we're talking about an intrusion,
we're talking about unauthorized access.

55
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:12.010
Not every access is good, okay,
but not every access is bad.

56
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:14.520
We need a way to distinguish that, right?

57
00:03:14.520 --> 00:03:16.250
So, inside of our networks,

58
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:19.650
we have what we call an intrusion
detection system that says, look hey,

59
00:03:19.650 --> 00:03:24.720
here's a packet that I see coming through
here and it's not supposed to be here.

60
00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:27.015
Well, what does an intrusion
detection system normally do?

61
00:03:27.015 --> 00:03:30.585
Well, at that point, it normally just
says, all right let me log that something

62
00:03:30.585 --> 00:03:34.101
bad has happened, and now let me go ahead
and send an email alert to Cherokee at 2

63
00:03:34.101 --> 00:03:37.170
o'clock in the morning letting her
know an intrusion has happened.

64
00:03:38.190 --> 00:03:42.630
On a host based intrusion detection
system, you're adding in that additional

65
00:03:42.630 --> 00:03:46.213
layer of security, just like Cherokee
was talking about in defense in depth,

66
00:03:46.213 --> 00:03:50.860
saying look, it might have gotten past my
network layer intrusion detection, but

67
00:03:50.860 --> 00:03:53.450
now, at the end user's computer,

68
00:03:53.450 --> 00:03:57.425
we can have another intrusion
detection system that alerts us,

69
00:03:57.425 --> 00:04:01.990
once again, to the very fact that
unauthorized access has happened, as well.

70
00:04:01.990 --> 00:04:06.800
So, instead of inspecting the data
when it arrives on the network,

71
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:11.720
it actually inspects the data as it comes
into the computer itself, as well, okay?

72
00:04:11.720 --> 00:04:14.260
Then, it continues to monitor,
what we call,

73
00:04:14.260 --> 00:04:19.320
the computer system state to detect
what programs are actually running,

74
00:04:19.320 --> 00:04:23.980
and whether or not any program is
accessing resources unusually.

75
00:04:23.980 --> 00:04:25.920
Now, how do you define unusually?

76
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:29.710
Well, that's up to every system, and the
way that the intrusion detection system

77
00:04:29.710 --> 00:04:32.480
is monitoring and saying,
here's what it is.

78
00:04:32.480 --> 00:04:35.390
So, there are limits that are set on
how you want to describe that and

79
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:40.470
how you want to define the way that that
system is being accessed unusually here.

80
00:04:40.470 --> 00:04:42.930
So there's no easy bar to say, here it is.

81
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:44.110
Here's what we have to do.

82
00:04:44.110 --> 00:04:45.270
But, that's where it begins.

83
00:04:45.270 --> 00:04:48.420
>> Right and I think we have even
covered that in a previous episode,

84
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:51.370
Ronnie, when we were talking about
the different types of analysis

85
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:53.370
engines whenever you're
dealing with these systems.

86
00:04:53.370 --> 00:04:57.680
Whether it be looking for
those anomalies via heuristics base or

87
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:00.910
signature and pattern things,
things like that, different options.

88
00:05:00.910 --> 00:05:04.190
>> Right, so let's take for an example
right, that you might end up finding

89
00:05:04.190 --> 00:05:09.960
yourself where a database program that
you got, well, this is a great program,

90
00:05:09.960 --> 00:05:13.450
but then it says, I need to access
every password on the machine.

91
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:15.010
Well, why would it do something like that?

92
00:05:15.010 --> 00:05:16.360
It doesn't seem to make sense.

93
00:05:16.360 --> 00:05:17.839
>> Out of the ordinary, yeah
>> Where there's a resource.

94
00:05:17.839 --> 00:05:18.971
Yes, out of the ordinary.

95
00:05:18.971 --> 00:05:20.345
But those are things that,

96
00:05:20.345 --> 00:05:24.070
hopefully, the intrusion detection
system is able to pick up.

97
00:05:24.070 --> 00:05:24.880
So, the neat thing is,

98
00:05:24.880 --> 00:05:27.740
even though we normally think about
intrusion detection as it just

99
00:05:27.740 --> 00:05:31.910
accessing or entering the system, and
that we need an order when that happens.

100
00:05:31.910 --> 00:05:36.960
A host based intrusion detection,
again remember, tells us that happens,

101
00:05:36.960 --> 00:05:41.480
but really monitors the state
of the computer for

102
00:05:41.480 --> 00:05:46.130
that unusual anomalous type of activity
that's happening on your system so

103
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:50.190
it can detect that and
then set an alert when it needs to, okay?

104
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:52.040
Now, this is a great idea.

105
00:05:52.040 --> 00:05:55.170
It really is something
worth taking a look at and

106
00:05:55.170 --> 00:05:59.600
worth making sure that if your end
user devices are expensive devices,

107
00:05:59.600 --> 00:06:03.560
are something that you're actually
gonna be using for a good long time,

108
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:08.290
it is worth taking a look at when
you put it onto your network.

109
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:11.040
There are problems with it,
though, too, okay?

110
00:06:11.040 --> 00:06:13.880
Unlike network intrusion
detection systems,

111
00:06:13.880 --> 00:06:18.220
on host based intrusion detection systems,
they have to be installed.

112
00:06:18.220 --> 00:06:18.820
And you can do that,

113
00:06:18.820 --> 00:06:22.920
you can deploy that in your application
deployment however you want to.

114
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:26.680
But, normally though, the configuration
though has to happen on each and

115
00:06:26.680 --> 00:06:28.590
every individual computer.

116
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:31.390
And that's because every
computer's actually done

117
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:33.850
where the user uses
a little bit differently.

118
00:06:33.850 --> 00:06:37.250
So, a single template,
you might begin there, but

119
00:06:37.250 --> 00:06:40.570
if you turn on some type of heuristic
feature, it's gonna take a bit of time

120
00:06:40.570 --> 00:06:44.110
before it actually is able to
figure out what's going on.

121
00:06:44.110 --> 00:06:47.230
But then,
it also takes a learning curve too, right?

122
00:06:47.230 --> 00:06:50.150
So you'll end up with false
the positives and false negatives and

123
00:06:50.150 --> 00:06:52.880
stuff like that,
that you also have to deal with too.

124
00:06:52.880 --> 00:06:56.936
So, just kind of realize that that it is
something else that you need to make sure

125
00:06:56.936 --> 00:06:59.620
that you inspect as you start doing this.

126
00:06:59.620 --> 00:07:04.520
The other thing, of course,
is the limitation of the host

127
00:07:04.520 --> 00:07:08.440
base intrusion detection system,
is that it only monitors itself.

128
00:07:08.440 --> 00:07:13.097
So, it can't tell you, it might be a
single machine that says, I know I'm safe,

129
00:07:13.097 --> 00:07:17.283
there might be 15 machines on the same
VLAN as that one machine that may be

130
00:07:17.283 --> 00:07:19.334
totally infected with something.

131
00:07:19.334 --> 00:07:21.020
It could be that.

132
00:07:21.020 --> 00:07:23.010
Does that mean that machine is safe?

133
00:07:23.010 --> 00:07:24.720
Heck no.
But, the very fact is,

134
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:28.010
it's the only thing that it
can do is monitor itself.

135
00:07:28.010 --> 00:07:30.751
So, it doesn't give any
extended coverage or

136
00:07:30.751 --> 00:07:35.192
any warning about other systems that
maybe infected out there too, okay?

137
00:07:35.192 --> 00:07:38.587
And, of course, the other thing that you
have to worry about with these is that

138
00:07:38.587 --> 00:07:39.942
they can be disabled, right?

139
00:07:39.942 --> 00:07:43.200
And the end user goes,
I don't need that, I'll just disable it.

140
00:07:43.200 --> 00:07:46.314
Or it can be disabled by software if
somebody's smart enough to figure out-

141
00:07:46.314 --> 00:07:47.240
>> A malicious, yeah.

142
00:07:47.240 --> 00:07:48.833
>> Figure out how to do this.

143
00:07:48.833 --> 00:07:53.280
They, of course, can take a look at that
particular point and do that as well.

144
00:07:53.280 --> 00:07:57.276
So, a lot of the systems that you
have in place, right, are like that.

145
00:07:57.276 --> 00:08:01.891
And it's kind of funny, for example, let's
take a look at my computer here just for

146
00:08:01.891 --> 00:08:02.478
a moment.

147
00:08:02.478 --> 00:08:05.839
When we start to take a look
at the idea of Windows,

148
00:08:05.839 --> 00:08:09.130
there is really a couple
of options that we have.

149
00:08:09.130 --> 00:08:14.650
And I'm must gonna type in,
at least I think I am, firewall here.

150
00:08:14.650 --> 00:08:17.670
And notice that there is
the Windows Firewall and

151
00:08:17.670 --> 00:08:22.320
then there is the Windows Firewall
with advanced security too, okay.

152
00:08:22.320 --> 00:08:26.860
Now these things really are great firewall
measures that are host based overall.

153
00:08:26.860 --> 00:08:31.060
But it's here on the Windows firewall
with advanced security, along with

154
00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:36.720
Windows Defender in combination with that,
that really does act like an intrusion

155
00:08:36.720 --> 00:08:42.100
detection system as well and
it can also be a prevention system too.

156
00:08:42.100 --> 00:08:47.040
So when you actually put all of it
together, it can do that in combination.

157
00:08:47.040 --> 00:08:49.130
But whereas this is just
a regular firewall,

158
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:52.540
this one with advanced security where
we can limit exactly what we want and

159
00:08:52.540 --> 00:08:54.918
limit the activity going in and
out of my computer.

160
00:08:54.918 --> 00:08:58.833
Well, that really is part of that
entire system that really more

161
00:08:58.833 --> 00:09:02.098
righteously belongs, or
more rightly, excuse me,

162
00:09:02.098 --> 00:09:05.810
belongs into the category
of intrusion prevention.

163
00:09:05.810 --> 00:09:10.010
But it is detecting what's
happening as data is moving in and

164
00:09:10.010 --> 00:09:11.610
out of your systems as well.

165
00:09:11.610 --> 00:09:16.650
So that's a good kind of basis for you to
think about when you start thinking about

166
00:09:16.650 --> 00:09:21.450
types of host-based detection systems
like what we're talking about as well.

167
00:09:21.450 --> 00:09:26.470
Okay, all right, so our next category
is actually two different ones and

168
00:09:26.470 --> 00:09:28.580
which could be very easily confused.

169
00:09:28.580 --> 00:09:32.276
All right Cherokee, so what is
the difference between anti virus and

170
00:09:32.276 --> 00:09:33.113
anti malware?

171
00:09:33.113 --> 00:09:34.250
What would you think?

172
00:09:34.250 --> 00:09:38.950
>> Well, looking at virus I'm just
thinking more signature definition

173
00:09:38.950 --> 00:09:42.960
based whereas the anti malware can be
a little bit more comprehensive in

174
00:09:42.960 --> 00:09:47.090
a sense that it covers more
than just well, viruses.

175
00:09:47.090 --> 00:09:50.230
So, we see a lot of different
types of malware being used today.

176
00:09:50.230 --> 00:09:55.840
So personally,
I try to use that term accordingly,

177
00:09:55.840 --> 00:09:58.480
because sometimes you can just
say them interchangeably,

178
00:09:58.480 --> 00:10:01.990
no one's going to really balk
at you too much for that.

179
00:10:01.990 --> 00:10:05.770
But we do wanna understand that there is a
difference between these two terms, right?

180
00:10:05.770 --> 00:10:07.660

>> And

00:05:21.240 --> 00:05:23.735

00:05:23.735 --> 00:05:25.750

00:05:45.650 --> 00:05:47.363

00:05:55.250 --> 00:05:57.500

00:06:04.717 --> 00:06:08.210
But we have this in concept,

00:06:08.210 --> 00:06:12.360

00:06:21.310 --> 00:06:23.973
Now if that attacker were to
